text: Paul, a bond-servant of Christ Jesus, called as an apostle, set apart for the gospel of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: which He promised beforehand through His prophets in the holy Scriptures,
speaker: Narrator

text: concerning His Son, who was born of a descendant of David according to the flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was declared the Son of God with power by the resurrection from the dead, according to the Spirit of holiness, Jesus Christ our Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: through whom we have received grace and apostleship to bring about the obedience of faith among all the Gentiles for His name’s sake,
speaker: Narrator

text: among whom you also are the called of Jesus Christ;
speaker: Narrator

text: to all who are beloved of God in Rome, called as saints: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all, because your faith is being proclaimed throughout the whole world.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God, whom I serve in my spirit in the preaching of the gospel of His Son, is my witness as to how unceasingly I make mention of you,
speaker: Narrator

text: always in my prayers making request, if perhaps now at last by the will of God I may succeed in coming to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I long to see you so that I may impart some spiritual gift to you, that you may be established;
speaker: Narrator

text: that is, that I may be encouraged together with you while among you, each of us by the other’s faith, both yours and mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do not want you to be unaware, brethren, that often I have planned to come to you (and have been prevented so far) so that I may obtain some fruit among you also, even as among the rest of the Gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am under obligation both to Greeks and to barbarians, both to the wise and to the foolish.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, for my part, I am eager to preach the gospel to you also who are in Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am not ashamed of the gospel, for it is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes, to the Jew first and also to the Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in it the righteousness of God is revealed from faith to faith; as it is written, “But the righteous man shall live by faith.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men who suppress the truth in unrighteousness,
speaker: Narrator

text: because that which is known about God is evident within them; for God made it evident to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For since the creation of the world His invisible attributes, His eternal power and divine nature, have been clearly seen, being understood through what has been made, so that they are without excuse.
speaker: Narrator

text: For even though they knew God, they did not honor Him as God or give thanks, but they became futile in their speculations, and their foolish heart was darkened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Professing to be wise, they became fools,
speaker: Narrator

text: and exchanged the glory of the incorruptible God for an image in the form of corruptible man and of birds and four-footed animals and crawling creatures.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore God gave them over in the lusts of their hearts to impurity, so that their bodies would be dishonored among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they exchanged the truth of God for a lie, and worshiped and served the creature rather than the Creator, who is blessed forever. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason God gave them over to degrading passions; for their women exchanged the natural function for that which is unnatural,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the same way also the men abandoned the natural function of the woman and burned in their desire toward one another, men with men committing indecent acts and receiving in their own persons the due penalty of their error.
speaker: Narrator

text: And just as they did not see fit to acknowledge God any longer, God gave them over to a depraved mind, to do those things which are not proper,
speaker: Narrator

text: being filled with all unrighteousness, wickedness, greed, evil; full of envy, murder, strife, deceit, malice; they are gossips,
speaker: Narrator

text: slanderers, haters of God, insolent, arrogant, boastful, inventors of evil, disobedient to parents,
speaker: Narrator

text: without understanding, untrustworthy, unloving, unmerciful;
speaker: Narrator

text: and although they know the ordinance of God, that those who practice such things are worthy of death, they not only do the same, but also give hearty approval to those who practice them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you have no excuse, everyone of you who passes judgment, for in that which you judge another, you condemn yourself; for you who judge practice the same things.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we know that the judgment of God rightly falls upon those who practice such things.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do you suppose this, O man, when you pass judgment on those who practice such things and do the same yourself, that you will escape the judgment of God?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you think lightly of the riches of His kindness and tolerance and patience, not knowing that the kindness of God leads you to repentance?
speaker: Narrator

text: But because of your stubbornness and unrepentant heart you are storing up wrath for yourself in the day of wrath and revelation of the righteous judgment of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: who will render to each person according to his deeds:
speaker: Narrator

text: to those who by perseverance in doing good seek for glory and honor and immortality, eternal life;
speaker: Narrator

text: but to those who are selfishly ambitious and do not obey the truth, but obey unrighteousness, wrath and indignation.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be tribulation and distress for every soul of man who does evil, of the Jew first and also of the Greek,
speaker: Narrator

text: but glory and honor and peace to everyone who does good, to the Jew first and also to the Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is no partiality with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all who have sinned without the Law will also perish without the Law, and all who have sinned under the Law will be judged by the Law;
speaker: Narrator

text: for it is not the hearers of the Law who are just before God, but the doers of the Law will be justified.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when Gentiles who do not have the Law do instinctively the things of the Law, these, not having the Law, are a law to themselves,
speaker: Narrator

text: in that they show the work of the Law written in their hearts, their conscience bearing witness and their thoughts alternately accusing or else defending them,
speaker: Narrator

text: on the day when, according to my gospel, God will judge the secrets of men through Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you bear the name “Jew” and rely upon the Law and boast in God,
speaker: Narrator

text: and know His will and approve the things that are essential, being instructed out of the Law,
speaker: Narrator

text: and are confident that you yourself are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text: a corrector of the foolish, a teacher of the immature, having in the Law the embodiment of knowledge and of the truth,
speaker: Narrator

text: you, therefore, who teach another, do you not teach yourself? You who preach that one shall not steal, do you steal?
speaker: Narrator

text: You who say that one should not commit adultery, do you commit adultery? You who abhor idols, do you rob temples?
speaker: Narrator

text: You who boast in the Law, through your breaking the Law, do you dishonor God?
speaker: Narrator

text: For “the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles because of you,” just as it is written.
speaker: Narrator

text: For indeed circumcision is of value if you practice the Law; but if you are a transgressor of the Law, your circumcision has become uncircumcision.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if the uncircumcised man keeps the requirements of the Law, will not his uncircumcision be regarded as circumcision?
speaker: Narrator

text: And he who is physically uncircumcised, if he keeps the Law, will he not judge you who though having the letter of the Law and circumcision are a transgressor of the Law?
speaker: Narrator

text: For he is not a Jew who is one outwardly, nor is circumcision that which is outward in the flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he is a Jew who is one inwardly; and circumcision is that which is of the heart, by the Spirit, not by the letter; and his praise is not from men, but from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then what advantage has the Jew? Or what is the benefit of circumcision?
speaker: Narrator

text: Great in every respect. First of all, that they were entrusted with the oracles of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? If some did not believe, their unbelief will not nullify the faithfulness of God, will it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
May it never be! Rather, let God be found true, though every man be found a liar, as it is written,
“That You may be justified in Your words,
And prevail when You are judged.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But if our unrighteousness demonstrates the righteousness of God, what shall we say? The God who inflicts wrath is not unrighteous, is He? (I am speaking in human terms.)
speaker: Narrator

text: May it never be! For otherwise, how will God judge the world?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if through my lie the truth of God abounded to His glory, why am I also still being judged as a sinner?
speaker: Narrator

text: And why not say (as we are slanderously reported and as some claim that we say), “Let us do evil that good may come”? Their condemnation is just.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? Are we better than they? Not at all; for we have already charged that both Jews and Greeks are all under sin;
speaker: Narrator

text:
as it is written,
“There is none righteous, not even one;
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is none who understands,
There is none who seeks for God;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: “Whose mouth is full of cursing and bitterness”;
speaker: Narrator

text: “Their feet are swift to shed blood,
speaker: Narrator

text: Destruction and misery are in their paths,
speaker: Narrator

text: And the path of peace they have not known.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “There is no fear of God before their eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now we know that whatever the Law says, it speaks to those who are under the Law, so that every mouth may be closed and all the world may become accountable to God;
speaker: Narrator

text: because by the works of the Law no flesh will be justified in His sight; for through the Law comes the knowledge of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now apart from the Law the righteousness of God has been manifested, being witnessed by the Law and the Prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: even the righteousness of God through faith in Jesus Christ for all those who believe; for there is no distinction;
speaker: Narrator

text: for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: being justified as a gift by His grace through the redemption which is in Christ Jesus;
speaker: Narrator

text: whom God displayed publicly as a propitiation in His blood through faith. This was to demonstrate His righteousness, because in the forbearance of God He passed over the sins previously committed;
speaker: Narrator

text: for the demonstration, I say, of His righteousness at the present time, so that He would be just and the justifier of the one who has faith in Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where then is boasting? It is excluded. By what kind of law? Of works? No, but by a law of faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we maintain that a man is justified by faith apart from works of the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or is God the God of Jews only? Is He not the God of Gentiles also? Yes, of Gentiles also,
speaker: Narrator

text: since indeed God who will justify the circumcised by faith and the uncircumcised through faith is one.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do we then nullify the Law through faith? May it never be! On the contrary, we establish the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then shall we say that Abraham, our forefather according to the flesh, has found?
speaker: Narrator

text: For if Abraham was justified by works, he has something to boast about, but not before God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what does the Scripture say? “Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now to the one who works, his wage is not credited as a favor, but as what is due.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to the one who does not work, but believes in Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is credited as righteousness,
speaker: Narrator

text: just as David also speaks of the blessing on the man to whom God credits righteousness apart from works:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Blessed are those whose lawless deeds have been forgiven,
And whose sins have been covered.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blessed is the man whose sin the Lord will not take into account.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this blessing then on the circumcised, or on the uncircumcised also? For we say, “Faith was credited to Abraham as righteousness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: How then was it credited? While he was circumcised, or uncircumcised? Not while circumcised, but while uncircumcised;
speaker: Narrator

text: and he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had while uncircumcised, so that he might be the father of all who believe without being circumcised, that righteousness might be credited to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the father of circumcision to those who not only are of the circumcision, but who also follow in the steps of the faith of our father Abraham which he had while uncircumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the promise to Abraham or to his descendants that he would be heir of the world was not through the Law, but through the righteousness of faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if those who are of the Law are heirs, faith is made void and the promise is nullified;
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Law brings about wrath, but where there is no law, there also is no violation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason it is by faith, in order that it may be in accordance with grace, so that the promise will be guaranteed to all the descendants, not only to those who are of the Law, but also to those who are of the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all,
speaker: Narrator

text: (as it is written, “A father of many nations have I made you”) in the presence of Him whom he believed, even God, who gives life to the dead and calls into being that which does not exist.
speaker: Narrator

text: In hope against hope he believed, so that he might become a father of many nations according to that which had been spoken, “So shall your descendants be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Without becoming weak in faith he contemplated his own body, now as good as dead since he was about a hundred years old, and the deadness of Sarah’s womb;
speaker: Narrator

text: yet, with respect to the promise of God, he did not waver in unbelief but grew strong in faith, giving glory to God,
speaker: Narrator

text: and being fully assured that what God had promised, He was able also to perform.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore it was also credited to him as righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now not for his sake only was it written that it was credited to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: but for our sake also, to whom it will be credited, as those who believe in Him who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead,
speaker: Narrator

text: He who was delivered over because of our transgressions, and was raised because of our justification.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, having been justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,
speaker: Narrator

text: through whom also we have obtained our introduction by faith into this grace in which we stand; and we exult in hope of the glory of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And not only this, but we also exult in our tribulations, knowing that tribulation brings about perseverance;
speaker: Narrator

text: and perseverance, proven character; and proven character, hope;
speaker: Narrator

text: and hope does not disappoint, because the love of God has been poured out within our hearts through the Holy Spirit who was given to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For while we were still helpless, at the right time Christ died for the ungodly.
speaker: Narrator

text: For one will hardly die for a righteous man; though perhaps for the good man someone would dare even to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God demonstrates His own love toward us, in that while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Much more then, having now been justified by His blood, we shall be saved from the wrath of God through Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if while we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of His Son, much more, having been reconciled, we shall be saved by His life.
speaker: Narrator

text: And not only this, but we also exult in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received the reconciliation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, just as through one man sin entered into the world, and death through sin, and so death spread to all men, because all sinned—
speaker: Narrator

text: for until the Law sin was in the world, but sin is not imputed when there is no law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless death reigned from Adam until Moses, even over those who had not sinned in the likeness of the offense of Adam, who is a type of Him who was to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the free gift is not like the transgression. For if by the transgression of the one the many died, much more did the grace of God and the gift by the grace of the one Man, Jesus Christ, abound to the many.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gift is not like that which came through the one who sinned; for on the one hand the judgment arose from one transgression resulting in condemnation, but on the other hand the free gift arose from many transgressions resulting in justification.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if by the transgression of the one, death reigned through the one, much more those who receive the abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness will reign in life through the One, Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then as through one transgression there resulted condemnation to all men, even so through one act of righteousness there resulted justification of life to all men.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as through the one man’s disobedience the many were made sinners, even so through the obedience of the One the many will be made righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Law came in so that the transgression would increase; but where sin increased, grace abounded all the more,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that, as sin reigned in death, even so grace would reign through righteousness to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: What shall we say then? Are we to continue in sin so that grace may increase?
speaker: Narrator

text: May it never be! How shall we who died to sin still live in it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you not know that all of us who have been baptized into Christ Jesus have been baptized into His death?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore we have been buried with Him through baptism into death, so that as Christ was raised from the dead through the glory of the Father, so we too might walk in newness of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if we have become united with Him in the likeness of His death, certainly we shall also be in the likeness of His resurrection,
speaker: Narrator

text: knowing this, that our old self was crucified with Him, in order that our body of sin might be done away with, so that we would no longer be slaves to sin;
speaker: Narrator

text: for he who has died is freed from sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if we have died with Christ, we believe that we shall also live with Him,
speaker: Narrator

text: knowing that Christ, having been raised from the dead, is never to die again; death no longer is master over Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the death that He died, He died to sin once for all; but the life that He lives, He lives to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so consider yourselves to be dead to sin, but alive to God in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore do not let sin reign in your mortal body so that you obey its lusts,
speaker: Narrator

text: and do not go on presenting the members of your body to sin as instruments of unrighteousness; but present yourselves to God as those alive from the dead, and your members as instruments of righteousness to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For sin shall not be master over you, for you are not under law but under grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? Shall we sin because we are not under law but under grace? May it never be!
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that when you present yourselves to someone as slaves for obedience, you are slaves of the one whom you obey, either of sin resulting in death, or of obedience resulting in righteousness?
speaker: Narrator

text: But thanks be to God that though you were slaves of sin, you became obedient from the heart to that form of teaching to which you were committed,
speaker: Narrator

text: and having been freed from sin, you became slaves of righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am speaking in human terms because of the weakness of your flesh. For just as you presented your members as slaves to impurity and to lawlessness, resulting in further lawlessness, so now present your members as slaves to righteousness, resulting in sanctification.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when you were slaves of sin, you were free in regard to righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore what benefit were you then deriving from the things of which you are now ashamed? For the outcome of those things is death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now having been freed from sin and enslaved to God, you derive your benefit, resulting in sanctification, and the outcome, eternal life.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you not know, brethren (for I am speaking to those who know the law), that the law has jurisdiction over a person as long as he lives?
speaker: Narrator

text: For the married woman is bound by law to her husband while he is living; but if her husband dies, she is released from the law concerning the husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, if while her husband is living she is joined to another man, she shall be called an adulteress; but if her husband dies, she is free from the law, so that she is not an adulteress though she is joined to another man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, my brethren, you also were made to die to the Law through the body of Christ, so that you might be joined to another, to Him who was raised from the dead, in order that we might bear fruit for God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For while we were in the flesh, the sinful passions, which were aroused by the Law, were at work in the members of our body to bear fruit for death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now we have been released from the Law, having died to that by which we were bound, so that we serve in newness of the Spirit and not in oldness of the letter.
speaker: Narrator

text: What shall we say then? Is the Law sin? May it never be! On the contrary, I would not have come to know sin except through the Law; for I would not have known about coveting if the Law had not said, “You shall not covet.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But sin, taking opportunity through the commandment, produced in me coveting of every kind; for apart from the Law sin is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was once alive apart from the Law; but when the commandment came, sin became alive and I died;
speaker: Narrator

text: and this commandment, which was to result in life, proved to result in death for me;
speaker: Narrator

text: for sin, taking an opportunity through the commandment, deceived me and through it killed me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, the Law is holy, and the commandment is holy and righteous and good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore did that which is good become a cause of death for me? May it never be! Rather it was sin, in order that it might be shown to be sin by effecting my death through that which is good, so that through the commandment sin would become utterly sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we know that the Law is spiritual, but I am of flesh, sold into bondage to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what I am doing, I do not understand; for I am not practicing what I would like to do, but I am doing the very thing I hate.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I do the very thing I do not want to do, I agree with the Law, confessing that the Law is good.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, no longer am I the one doing it, but sin which dwells in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I know that nothing good dwells in me, that is, in my flesh; for the willing is present in me, but the doing of the good is not.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the good that I want, I do not do, but I practice the very evil that I do not want.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I am doing the very thing I do not want, I am no longer the one doing it, but sin which dwells in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I find then the principle that evil is present in me, the one who wants to do good.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I joyfully concur with the law of God in the inner man,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I see a different law in the members of my body, waging war against the law of my mind and making me a prisoner of the law of sin which is in my members.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wretched man that I am! Who will set me free from the body of this death?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then, on the one hand I myself with my mind am serving the law of God, but on the other, with my flesh the law of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has set you free from the law of sin and of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what the Law could not do, weak as it was through the flesh, God did: sending His own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh and as an offering for sin, He condemned sin in the flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the requirement of the Law might be fulfilled in us, who do not walk according to the flesh but according to the Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who are according to the flesh set their minds on the things of the flesh, but those who are according to the Spirit, the things of the Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the mind set on the flesh is death, but the mind set on the Spirit is life and peace,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the mind set on the flesh is hostile toward God; for it does not subject itself to the law of God, for it is not even able to do so,
speaker: Narrator

text: and those who are in the flesh cannot please God.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you are not in the flesh but in the Spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God dwells in you. But if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ, he does not belong to Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If Christ is in you, though the body is dead because of sin, yet the spirit is alive because of righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the Spirit of Him who raised Jesus from the dead dwells in you, He who raised Christ Jesus from the dead will also give life to your mortal bodies through His Spirit who dwells in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, brethren, we are under obligation, not to the flesh, to live according to the flesh—
speaker: Narrator

text: for if you are living according to the flesh, you must die; but if by the Spirit you are putting to death the deeds of the body, you will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all who are being led by the Spirit of God, these are sons of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you have not received a spirit of slavery leading to fear again, but you have received a spirit of adoption as sons by which we cry out, “Abba! Father!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit Himself testifies with our spirit that we are children of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if children, heirs also, heirs of God and fellow heirs with Christ, if indeed we suffer with Him so that we may also be glorified with Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory that is to be revealed to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the anxious longing of the creation waits eagerly for the revealing of the sons of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the creation was subjected to futility, not willingly, but because of Him who subjected it, in hope
speaker: Narrator

text: that the creation itself also will be set free from its slavery to corruption into the freedom of the glory of the children of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we know that the whole creation groans and suffers the pains of childbirth together until now.
speaker: Narrator

text: And not only this, but also we ourselves, having the first fruits of the Spirit, even we ourselves groan within ourselves, waiting eagerly for our adoption as sons, the redemption of our body.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in hope we have been saved, but hope that is seen is not hope; for who hopes for what he already sees?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we hope for what we do not see, with perseverance we wait eagerly for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way the Spirit also helps our weakness; for we do not know how to pray as we should, but the Spirit Himself intercedes for us with groanings too deep for words;
speaker: Narrator

text: and He who searches the hearts knows what the mind of the Spirit is, because He intercedes for the saints according to the will of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we know that God causes all things to work together for good to those who love God, to those who are called according to His purpose.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those whom He foreknew, He also predestined to become conformed to the image of His Son, so that He would be the firstborn among many brethren;
speaker: Narrator

text: and these whom He predestined, He also called; and these whom He called, He also justified; and these whom He justified, He also glorified.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then shall we say to these things? If God is for us, who is against us?
speaker: Narrator

text: He who did not spare His own Son, but delivered Him over for us all, how will He not also with Him freely give us all things?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who will bring a charge against God’s elect? God is the one who justifies;
speaker: Narrator

text: who is the one who condemns? Christ Jesus is He who died, yes, rather who was raised, who is at the right hand of God, who also intercedes for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who will separate us from the love of Christ? Will tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: But in all these things we overwhelmingly conquer through Him who loved us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am convinced that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor things present, nor things to come, nor powers,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor height, nor depth, nor any other created thing, will be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am telling the truth in Christ, I am not lying, my conscience testifies with me in the Holy Spirit,
speaker: Narrator

text: that I have great sorrow and unceasing grief in my heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I could wish that I myself were accursed, separated from Christ for the sake of my brethren, my kinsmen according to the flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: who are Israelites, to whom belongs the adoption as sons, and the glory and the covenants and the giving of the Law and the temple service and the promises,
speaker: Narrator

text: whose are the fathers, and from whom is the Christ according to the flesh, who is over all, God blessed forever. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it is not as though the word of God has failed. For they are not all Israel who are descended from Israel;
speaker: Narrator

text: nor are they all children because they are Abraham’s descendants, but: “through Isaac your descendants will be named.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That is, it is not the children of the flesh who are children of God, but the children of the promise are regarded as descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is the word of promise: “At this time I will come, and Sarah shall have a son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And not only this, but there was Rebekah also, when she had conceived twins by one man, our father Isaac;
speaker: Narrator

text: for though the twins were not yet born and had not done anything good or bad, so that God’s purpose according to His choice would stand, not because of works but because of Him who calls,
speaker: Narrator

text: it was said to her, “The older will serve the younger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as it is written, “Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What shall we say then? There is no injustice with God, is there? May it never be!
speaker: Narrator

text: For He says to Moses, “I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So then it does not depend on the man who wills or the man who runs, but on God who has mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Scripture says to Pharaoh, “For this very purpose I raised you up, to demonstrate My power in you, and that My name might be proclaimed throughout the whole earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So then He has mercy on whom He desires, and He hardens whom He desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will say to me then, “Why does He still find fault? For who resists His will?”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the contrary, who are you, O man, who answers back to God? The thing molded will not say to the molder, “Why did you make me like this,” will it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or does not the potter have a right over the clay, to make from the same lump one vessel for honorable use and another for common use?
speaker: Narrator

text: What if God, although willing to demonstrate His wrath and to make His power known, endured with much patience vessels of wrath prepared for destruction?
speaker: Narrator

text: And He did so to make known the riches of His glory upon vessels of mercy, which He prepared beforehand for glory,
speaker: Narrator

text: even us, whom He also called, not from among Jews only, but also from among Gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As He says also in Hosea,
“I will call those who were not My people, ‘My people,’
And her who was not beloved, ‘beloved.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And it shall be that in the place where it was said to them, ‘you are not My people,’
There they shall be called sons of the living God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaiah cries out concerning Israel, “Though the number of the sons of Israel be like the sand of the sea, it is the remnant that will be saved;
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Lord will execute His word on the earth, thoroughly and quickly.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And just as Isaiah foretold,
“Unless the Lord of Sabaoth had left to us a posterity,
We would have become like Sodom, and would have resembled Gomorrah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What shall we say then? That Gentiles, who did not pursue righteousness, attained righteousness, even the righteousness which is by faith;
speaker: Narrator

text: but Israel, pursuing a law of righteousness, did not arrive at that law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why? Because they did not pursue it by faith, but as though it were by works. They stumbled over the stumbling stone,
speaker: Narrator

text:
just as it is written,
“Behold, I lay in Zion a stone of stumbling and a rock of offense,
And he who believes in Him will not be disappointed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Brethren, my heart’s desire and my prayer to God for them is for their salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I testify about them that they have a zeal for God, but not in accordance with knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: For not knowing about God’s righteousness and seeking to establish their own, they did not subject themselves to the righteousness of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to everyone who believes.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Moses writes that the man who practices the righteousness which is based on law shall live by that righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the righteousness based on faith speaks as follows: “Do not say in your heart, ‘Who will ascend into heaven?’ (that is, to bring Christ down),
speaker: Narrator

text: or ‘Who will descend into the abyss?’ (that is, to bring Christ up from the dead).”
speaker: Narrator

text: But what does it say? “The word is near you, in your mouth and in your heart”—that is, the word of faith which we are preaching,
speaker: Narrator

text: that if you confess with your mouth Jesus as Lord, and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be saved;
speaker: Narrator

text: for with the heart a person believes, resulting in righteousness, and with the mouth he confesses, resulting in salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Scripture says, “Whoever believes in Him will not be disappointed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is no distinction between Jew and Greek; for the same Lord is Lord of all, abounding in riches for all who call on Him;
speaker: Narrator

text: for “Whoever will call on the name of the Lord will be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: How then will they call on Him in whom they have not believed? How will they believe in Him whom they have not heard? And how will they hear without a preacher?
speaker: Narrator

text: How will they preach unless they are sent? Just as it is written, “How beautiful are the feet of those who bring good news of good things!”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, they did not all heed the good news; for Isaiah says, “Lord, who has believed our report?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So faith comes from hearing, and hearing by the word of Christ.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But I say, surely Israel did not know, did they? First Moses says,
“I will make you jealous by that which is not a nation,
By a nation without understanding will I anger you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Isaiah is very bold and says,
“I was found by those who did not seek Me,
I became manifest to those who did not ask for Me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for Israel He says, “All the day long I have stretched out My hands to a disobedient and obstinate people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I say then, God has not rejected His people, has He? May it never be! For I too am an Israelite, a descendant of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: God has not rejected His people whom He foreknew. Or do you not know what the Scripture says in the passage about Elijah, how he pleads with God against Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Lord, they have killed Your prophets, they have torn down Your altars, and I alone am left, and they are seeking my life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But what is the divine response to him? “I have kept for Myself seven thousand men who have not bowed the knee to Baal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way then, there has also come to be at the present time a remnant according to God’s gracious choice.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it is by grace, it is no longer on the basis of works, otherwise grace is no longer grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? What Israel is seeking, it has not obtained, but those who were chosen obtained it, and the rest were hardened;
speaker: Narrator

text:
just as it is written,
“God gave them a spirit of stupor,
Eyes to see not and ears to hear not,
Down to this very day.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And David says,
“Let their table become a snare and a trap,
And a stumbling block and a retribution to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Let their eyes be darkened to see not,
And bend their backs forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I say then, they did not stumble so as to fall, did they? May it never be! But by their transgression salvation has come to the Gentiles, to make them jealous.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if their transgression is riches for the world and their failure is riches for the Gentiles, how much more will their fulfillment be!
speaker: Narrator

text: But I am speaking to you who are Gentiles. Inasmuch then as I am an apostle of Gentiles, I magnify my ministry,
speaker: Narrator

text: if somehow I might move to jealousy my fellow countrymen and save some of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if their rejection is the reconciliation of the world, what will their acceptance be but life from the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: If the first piece of dough is holy, the lump is also; and if the root is holy, the branches are too.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if some of the branches were broken off, and you, being a wild olive, were grafted in among them and became partaker with them of the rich root of the olive tree,
speaker: Narrator

text: do not be arrogant toward the branches; but if you are arrogant, remember that it is not you who supports the root, but the root supports you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will say then, “Branches were broken off so that I might be grafted in.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Quite right, they were broken off for their unbelief, but you stand by your faith. Do not be conceited, but fear;
speaker: Narrator

text: for if God did not spare the natural branches, He will not spare you, either.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold then the kindness and severity of God; to those who fell, severity, but to you, God’s kindness, if you continue in His kindness; otherwise you also will be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they also, if they do not continue in their unbelief, will be grafted in, for God is able to graft them in again.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you were cut off from what is by nature a wild olive tree, and were grafted contrary to nature into a cultivated olive tree, how much more will these who are the natural branches be grafted into their own olive tree?
speaker: Narrator

text: For I do not want you, brethren, to be uninformed of this mystery—so that you will not be wise in your own estimation—that a partial hardening has happened to Israel until the fullness of the Gentiles has come in;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and so all Israel will be saved; just as it is written,
“The Deliverer will come from Zion,
He will remove ungodliness from Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is My covenant with them,
When I take away their sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From the standpoint of the gospel they are enemies for your sake, but from the standpoint of God’s choice they are beloved for the sake of the fathers;
speaker: Narrator

text: for the gifts and the calling of God are irrevocable.
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as you once were disobedient to God, but now have been shown mercy because of their disobedience,
speaker: Narrator

text: so these also now have been disobedient, that because of the mercy shown to you they also may now be shown mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God has shut up all in disobedience so that He may show mercy to all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oh, the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are His judgments and unfathomable His ways!
speaker: Narrator

text: For who has known the mind of the Lord, or who became His counselor?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or who has first given to Him that it might be paid back to him again?
speaker: Narrator

text: For from Him and through Him and to Him are all things. To Him be the glory forever. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I urge you, brethren, by the mercies of God, to present your bodies a living and holy sacrifice, acceptable to God, which is your spiritual service of worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: And do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind, so that you may prove what the will of God is, that which is good and acceptable and perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: For through the grace given to me I say to everyone among you not to think more highly of himself than he ought to think; but to think so as to have sound judgment, as God has allotted to each a measure of faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as we have many members in one body and all the members do not have the same function,
speaker: Narrator

text: so we, who are many, are one body in Christ, and individually members one of another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since we have gifts that differ according to the grace given to us, each of us is to exercise them accordingly: if prophecy, according to the proportion of his faith;
speaker: Narrator

text: if service, in his serving; or he who teaches, in his teaching;
speaker: Narrator

text: or he who exhorts, in his exhortation; he who gives, with liberality; he who leads, with diligence; he who shows mercy, with cheerfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let love be without hypocrisy. Abhor what is evil; cling to what is good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be devoted to one another in brotherly love; give preference to one another in honor;
speaker: Narrator

text: not lagging behind in diligence, fervent in spirit, serving the Lord;
speaker: Narrator

text: rejoicing in hope, persevering in tribulation, devoted to prayer,
speaker: Narrator

text: contributing to the needs of the saints, practicing hospitality.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bless those who persecute you; bless and do not curse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice with those who rejoice, and weep with those who weep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be of the same mind toward one another; do not be haughty in mind, but associate with the lowly. Do not be wise in your own estimation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never pay back evil for evil to anyone. Respect what is right in the sight of all men.
speaker: Narrator

text: If possible, so far as it depends on you, be at peace with all men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never take your own revenge, beloved, but leave room for the wrath of God, for it is written, “Vengeance is Mine, I will repay,” says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if your enemy is hungry, feed him, and if he is thirsty, give him a drink; for in so doing you will heap burning coals on his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every person is to be in subjection to the governing authorities. For there is no authority except from God, and those which exist are established by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore whoever resists authority has opposed the ordinance of God; and they who have opposed will receive condemnation upon themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For rulers are not a cause of fear for good behavior, but for evil. Do you want to have no fear of authority? Do what is good and you will have praise from the same;
speaker: Narrator

text: for it is a minister of God to you for good. But if you do what is evil, be afraid; for it does not bear the sword for nothing; for it is a minister of God, an avenger who brings wrath on the one who practices evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore it is necessary to be in subjection, not only because of wrath, but also for conscience’ sake.
speaker: Narrator

text: For because of this you also pay taxes, for rulers are servants of God, devoting themselves to this very thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Render to all what is due them: tax to whom tax is due; custom to whom custom; fear to whom fear; honor to whom honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Owe nothing to anyone except to love one another; for he who loves his neighbor has fulfilled the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this, “You shall not commit adultery, You shall not murder, You shall not steal, You shall not covet,” and if there is any other commandment, it is summed up in this saying, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Love does no wrong to a neighbor; therefore love is the fulfillment of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this, knowing the time, that it is already the hour for you to awaken from sleep; for now salvation is nearer to us than when we believed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The night is almost gone, and the day is near. Therefore let us lay aside the deeds of darkness and put on the armor of light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us behave properly as in the day, not in carousing and drunkenness, not in sexual promiscuity and sensuality, not in strife and jealousy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make no provision for the flesh in regard to its lusts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now accept the one who is weak in faith, but not for the purpose of passing judgment on his opinions.
speaker: Narrator

text: One person has faith that he may eat all things, but he who is weak eats vegetables only.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who eats is not to regard with contempt the one who does not eat, and the one who does not eat is not to judge the one who eats, for God has accepted him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who are you to judge the servant of another? To his own master he stands or falls; and he will stand, for the Lord is able to make him stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: One person regards one day above another, another regards every day alike. Each person must be fully convinced in his own mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who observes the day, observes it for the Lord, and he who eats, does so for the Lord, for he gives thanks to God; and he who eats not, for the Lord he does not eat, and gives thanks to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For not one of us lives for himself, and not one dies for himself;
speaker: Narrator

text: for if we live, we live for the Lord, or if we die, we die for the Lord; therefore whether we live or die, we are the Lord’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: For to this end Christ died and lived again, that He might be Lord both of the dead and of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, why do you judge your brother? Or you again, why do you regard your brother with contempt? For we will all stand before the judgment seat of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is written,
“As I live, says the Lord, every knee shall bow to Me,
And every tongue shall give praise to God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So then each one of us will give an account of himself to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore let us not judge one another anymore, but rather determine this—not to put an obstacle or a stumbling block in a brother’s way.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know and am convinced in the Lord Jesus that nothing is unclean in itself; but to him who thinks anything to be unclean, to him it is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if because of food your brother is hurt, you are no longer walking according to love. Do not destroy with your food him for whom Christ died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore do not let what is for you a good thing be spoken of as evil;
speaker: Narrator

text: for the kingdom of God is not eating and drinking, but righteousness and peace and joy in the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he who in this way serves Christ is acceptable to God and approved by men.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then we pursue the things which make for peace and the building up of one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not tear down the work of God for the sake of food. All things indeed are clean, but they are evil for the man who eats and gives offense.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is good not to eat meat or to drink wine, or to do anything by which your brother stumbles.
speaker: Narrator

text: The faith which you have, have as your own conviction before God. Happy is he who does not condemn himself in what he approves.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he who doubts is condemned if he eats, because his eating is not from faith; and whatever is not from faith is sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now we who are strong ought to bear the weaknesses of those without strength and not just please ourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of us is to please his neighbor for his good, to his edification.
speaker: Narrator

text: For even Christ did not please Himself; but as it is written, “The reproaches of those who reproached You fell on Me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For whatever was written in earlier times was written for our instruction, so that through perseverance and the encouragement of the Scriptures we might have hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may the God who gives perseverance and encouragement grant you to be of the same mind with one another according to Christ Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that with one accord you may with one voice glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, accept one another, just as Christ also accepted us to the glory of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I say that Christ has become a servant to the circumcision on behalf of the truth of God to confirm the promises given to the fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and for the Gentiles to glorify God for His mercy; as it is written,
“Therefore I will give praise to You among the Gentiles,
And I will sing to Your name.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Again he says,
“Rejoice, O Gentiles, with His people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And again,
“Praise the Lord all you Gentiles,
And let all the peoples praise Him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Again Isaiah says,
“There shall come the root of Jesse,
And He who arises to rule over the Gentiles,
In Him shall the Gentiles hope.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, so that you will abound in hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: And concerning you, my brethren, I myself also am convinced that you yourselves are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge and able also to admonish one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have written very boldly to you on some points so as to remind you again, because of the grace that was given me from God,
speaker: Narrator

text: to be a minister of Christ Jesus to the Gentiles, ministering as a priest the gospel of God, so that my offering of the Gentiles may become acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore in Christ Jesus I have found reason for boasting in things pertaining to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will not presume to speak of anything except what Christ has accomplished through me, resulting in the obedience of the Gentiles by word and deed,
speaker: Narrator

text: in the power of signs and wonders, in the power of the Spirit; so that from Jerusalem and round about as far as Illyricum I have fully preached the gospel of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: And thus I aspired to preach the gospel, not where Christ was already named, so that I would not build on another man’s foundation;
speaker: Narrator

text:
but as it is written,
“They who had no news of Him shall see,
And they who have not heard shall understand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason I have often been prevented from coming to you;
speaker: Narrator

text: but now, with no further place for me in these regions, and since I have had for many years a longing to come to you
speaker: Narrator

text: whenever I go to Spain—for I hope to see you in passing, and to be helped on my way there by you, when I have first enjoyed your company for a while—
speaker: Narrator

text: but now, I am going to Jerusalem serving the saints.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Macedonia and Achaia have been pleased to make a contribution for the poor among the saints in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, they were pleased to do so, and they are indebted to them. For if the Gentiles have shared in their spiritual things, they are indebted to minister to them also in material things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, when I have finished this, and have put my seal on this fruit of theirs, I will go on by way of you to Spain.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know that when I come to you, I will come in the fullness of the blessing of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I urge you, brethren, by our Lord Jesus Christ and by the love of the Spirit, to strive together with me in your prayers to God for me,
speaker: Narrator

text: that I may be rescued from those who are disobedient in Judea, and that my service for Jerusalem may prove acceptable to the saints;
speaker: Narrator

text: so that I may come to you in joy by the will of God and find refreshing rest in your company.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the God of peace be with you all. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: I commend to you our sister Phoebe, who is a servant of the church which is at Cenchrea;
speaker: Narrator

text: that you receive her in the Lord in a manner worthy of the saints, and that you help her in whatever matter she may have need of you; for she herself has also been a helper of many, and of myself as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Prisca and Aquila, my fellow workers in Christ Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: who for my life risked their own necks, to whom not only do I give thanks, but also all the churches of the Gentiles;
speaker: Narrator

text: also greet the church that is in their house. Greet Epaenetus, my beloved, who is the first convert to Christ from Asia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Mary, who has worked hard for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Andronicus and Junias, my kinsmen and my fellow prisoners, who are outstanding among the apostles, who also were in Christ before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Ampliatus, my beloved in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Urbanus, our fellow worker in Christ, and Stachys my beloved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Apelles, the approved in Christ. Greet those who are of the household of Aristobulus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Herodion, my kinsman. Greet those of the household of Narcissus, who are in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Tryphaena and Tryphosa, workers in the Lord. Greet Persis the beloved, who has worked hard in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Rufus, a choice man in the Lord, also his mother and mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas and the brethren with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Philologus and Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and all the saints who are with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the churches of Christ greet you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I urge you, brethren, keep your eye on those who cause dissensions and hindrances contrary to the teaching which you learned, and turn away from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For such men are slaves, not of our Lord Christ but of their own appetites; and by their smooth and flattering speech they deceive the hearts of the unsuspecting.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the report of your obedience has reached to all; therefore I am rejoicing over you, but I want you to be wise in what is good and innocent in what is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet.
The grace of our Lord Jesus be with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Timothy my fellow worker greets you, and so do Lucius and Jason and Sosipater, my kinsmen.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, Tertius, who write this letter, greet you in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaius, host to me and to the whole church, greets you. Erastus, the city treasurer greets you, and Quartus, the brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: [The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.]
speaker: Narrator

text: Now to Him who is able to establish you according to my gospel and the preaching of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery which has been kept secret for long ages past,
speaker: Narrator

text: but now is manifested, and by the Scriptures of the prophets, according to the commandment of the eternal God, has been made known to all the nations, leading to obedience of faith;
speaker: Narrator

text: to the only wise God, through Jesus Christ, be the glory forever. Amen.
speaker: Narrator
